titlestmt.titleproper: A Guide to the Ford Foundation records, Press Materials FA1322

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2019-03-06 14:05:36 -0500.

physdesc.extent: 152 Hollinger boxes and 1 oversize document box

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Collection contains different types of press material from 1951 to 2002 that document the Ford Foundation's efforts to both publicize itself in the news and acquire media commentary on its ventures. Four main press material types are featured in the collection: 1) press releases, 2) press clippings, 3) press conference and news briefing materials, and 4) radio and television press media. Each of these material types are housed within a separate series. A fifth series holds oversize magazine articles from the late 1960s that largely concern the architecture and design of the new Ford Foundation headquarters building in New York City.

The Ford Foundation's publicity strategy for this time period is most consistently documented by the News from the Ford Foundation press releases in Series 1. These releases belong to an organized system of press releases compiled by the Ford Foundation Office of Reports between 1951 and 1975. Likewise, the Ford Foundation's attempts to collect media commentary on its activities is most consistently documented by the press clippings in Series 2. These clippings were sent to the Ford Foundation Office of Communications by press clipping service providers Burrelle's Information Services and Luce Press Clippings in the 1990s and early 2000s.

Besides press releases and press clippings, the collection contains materials such as correspondence, reports, publications, invoices, radio and television broadcast transcripts, mailing lists, invitation lists, and press logs. There are also a few files that house photographs.

Documents in the collection concern such broad topics as philanthropy, international relations, economic development, the arts and humanities, social justice, civil rights, community development, energy policy, state and local government, population and family planning, and education among others. More specific subjects include immigration, women's rights, women in the workplace, LGBT social activism, diversity in higher educaiton, the reorganization of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP), the growth of the Gates Foundation, public suspicion and criticism of government, the 1990s Million Man March, the decentralization of New York City public schools, the appointments of various Ford Foundation presidents, international studies programs, the U.S. House of Representatives investigation into tax-exempt foundations in the 1950s, the role of black fathers, fellowships for various kinds of artists, musicians, and writers, business education, and funding for public broadcasting.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Information regarding the Rockefeller Archive Center's preferred elements and forms of citation can be found at http://www.rockarch.org/research/citations.php

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Ford Foundation archive was deposited at the RAC in 2011. Ford Foundation records, correspondence, reports, program files and officers papers were transferred to, and accessioned by, RAC beginning in 2011. Accessions continue as necesary.

The first set of Ford Foundation Press Materials was transferred to the RAC in 2017 by the Ford Foundation and was ingested by the RAC as Accessions 2017:062 and 2017:078. These accessions make up Ford Foundation records, Press Materials, Record Group 1.
Another set of press materials was transferred to the RAC in 2018 and ingested as Accession 2018:088. This accession makes up Ford Foundation records, Press Materials, Record Group 2.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: RAC users must abide by all applicable provisions of United States copyright law. Reproduction/duplication of archival items is routinely provided in accordance with "fair use". If the RAC does not hold copyright for an archival collection, or items within a collection, it is the users responsibility to contact the copyright holder, or make a fair effort to do so, prior to publication.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged into two different record groups, seven series, and seventeen subseries.

Record Group 1 contains the first two accessions (2017:063 and 2017:078) of Ford Foundation press materials transferred to the Rockefeller Archive Center and was originally described as a stand-alone collection. Those documents were then represented as a record group when another accession of press materials was received after the first two had been processed. Record Group 2 holds this accession (2018:088).

There were obvious relationships between documents in the processed collection and documents in the new accession, but it was decided during the processing of Accession 2018:088 to represent these connections though the implementation of different records groups within a larger collection rather than to try to integrate the documents in 2018:088 into the established Ford Foundation Press Materials collection. The exception to this strategy occurred with the insertion of News from the Ford Foundation press releases, No. 676-735 from Accession 2018:088 into Record Group 1. Those documents filled a clear gap in the first record group's holdings, and it required minimal interference to restore that contextual relationship.
If future transfers of large amounts of press materials occur, those documents will likely be represented as additional record groups in the collection.
Original order was maintained as much as possible in arranging the collection.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Ford Foundation was chartered by Henry and Edsel Ford in 1936 "to receive and administer funds for scientific, educational and charitable purposes, all for the public welfare", and initially served the Ford family's charitable interests in the Detroit area. Following the deaths of Edsel Ford (1943) and Henry Ford (1947), the Foundation was propelled to the forefront of philanthropy as the largest American foundation in terms of both endowment and yearly expenditures, and with an international scope to its major program areas.

During the Foundation's first twenty years its major programs were in international economic development, primary and higher education, educational and public broadcasting, behavioral sciences, civil liberties, urban development, fine arts and the humanities. The Ford Foundation also partnered with the Rockefeller Foundation in supporting agricultural development in South America, Africa, and Southeast Asia. Since the 1970s, the Foundation has also pioneered programs in women's rights, energy policy, micro-financing in under-developed countries, establishing human rights groups, and improving international HIV/AIDS education.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The record group is divided into five series and eight subseries.

The first four series reflect how the record group material was grouped within the original storage containers of Ford Foundation Press Materials Accessions 2017:062 and 2017:078. Documents appeared to have been organized according to press material type. For instance, some boxes predominately housed press clippings while others predominately housed radio and television press media. The two main press material types discerned during processing were press releases (Series 1) and press clippings (Series 2). They both spanned multiple boxes, encompassing the vast bulk of the collection. The other two press material types – press conference and news briefing materials (Series 3) and radio and television press media (Series 4) – only occupied two respective boxes. However, the materials in both boxes appeared to comprise two distinct groupings of collection material and were therefore represented as separate series.

The last series consists of four large magazine articles. These articles did not appear to possess any relationship to the groupings of materials found within the other boxes. In consideration of this and of the oversize containers needed to properly house the materials, the articles were included at the end of the collection as a fifth series.

The first two series were divided into eight subseries (four for Series 1 and four for Series 2) during processing. These subseries represent identified systems of organization within the press release and press clipping groupings, and they help to facilitate improved user access to the large quantity of records that each series possesses.
Record group arrangement is as follows:

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This record group contains the first two sets of Ford Foundation press materials transferred to and processed by the Rockefeller Archive Center. They were ingested in 2017 as Accessions 2017:062 and 2017:078 and were described together in the collection finding aid in 2018.

Within the record group, there are four main types of press material: 1) press releases, 2) press clippings, 3) press conference and news briefing materials, and 4) radio and television press media. Each of these material types are housed within a separate series. A fifth series holds oversize magazine articles from the late 1960s that largely concern the architecture and design of the new Ford Foundation headquarters building in New York City.

The Ford Foundation's publicity strategy for this time period is most consistently documented by the News from the Ford Foundation press releases in Series 1. These releases belong to an organized system of press releases compiled by the Ford Foundation Office of Reports between 1951 and 1975. Likewise, the Ford Foundation's attempts to collect media commentary on its activities is most consistently documented by the press clippings in Series 2. These clippings were sent to the Ford Foundation Office of Communications by press clipping service providers Burrelle's Information Services and Luce Press Clippings in the 1990s and early 2000s.

A small amount of material was integrated into the record group from Record Group 2 in order to restore obvious contextual relationships between materials. Similar actions may occur again if future accessions of Ford Foundation press material are transferred to the Archive Center, and the new files fill evident gaps in Record Group 1's holdings.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The series was broken into four subseries during processing in order to represent the two original systems of arrangement found within the series as well as to facilitate improved user access to the large number of files containing the Ford Foundation's press releases. The first three subseries contain press releases that were included within a numbering system devised possibly by the Ford Foundation Office of Reports or by any other entity involved with the creation and/or custodianship of the records. These releases were then divided further into separate subseries based on chronological groupings. The chronological system of arrangement for the first three subseries helps to identify gaps in the records that the record group holds. For example, users can see that the series does not contain press releases No. 296-369 (1962-1964).
The integration of press releases No. 676-735 (July 1969 – July 1970) from Record Group 2 after the rest of the series had been processed and described helped fill another one of these gaps.
The fourth subseries consists of press release job files from the early 1990s that were organized by topic and job number.
The series arrangement is as follows:
Series 1. Subseries 1. News from the Ford Foundation releases No. 1-295, 1951-1962
Series 1. Subseries 2. News from the Ford Foundation releases No. 370-771, 1964-1970
Series 1. Subseries 3. News from the Ford Foundation releases No. 829-1005, 1972-1975
Series 1. Subseries 4. Press release job files, 1990-1993

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series primarily consists of Ford Foundation press releases that were published between 1951 and 1975 and between 1990 and 1993. The Foundation disseminated these press releases in order to share news of its latest organizational developments as well as to publicize the most recent and upcoming actions of its various philanthropic programs. Position appointments, grant distributions, fellowship award winners, program expansions, and published reports are all common announcements featured in the series.

Within the series, the 1951-1975 press release files are distinct from the 1990-1993 files in terms of more than just dates. The 1951-1975 files (with the exception of a few in Series 1 Subseries 1) consist of single press releases that have been organized into a numbered system of news announcements either by the Ford Foundation Office of Reports or by another entity involved with the creation and/or custodianship of the records. These files are all titled News from the Ford Foundation, and they make up the first three subseries. In contrast to the News from the Ford Foundation files, the 1990-1993 press release files contain much more than the finished versions of the disseminated news announcements. They are job files that document how the Ford Foundation created, advertised, and published its press releases. They make up the fourth subseries.

While all files are titled News from the Ford Foundation in the first three subseries, not all of the actual press releases within those files bear that title. It appears that the records creators adopted that name to reference the entire system of press releases that they organized and numbered. The News from the Ford Foundation system has put the press releases into a mostly chronological order. Obvious revisions to the system indicate that it does not perfectly encompass every press release ever disseminated by the Ford Foundation because the records creators had to go back and add files to the system with numbers like 247a. Furthermore, evident gaps in the series' press release holdings show that the record group does not house the entire News from the Ford Foundation press release system (News from the Ford Foundation press releases No. 676-735 (July 1969 – July 1970) in Series 1 Subseries 2 were originally housed in Record Group 2 and were integrated into this series during the processing of that record group). The records creators also sorted a few unnumbered press releases in other parts of the record group (Series 3 and Series 4).

Although all of the News from the Ford Foundation press releases were numbered, not all of them had titles that described their content. Titles were therefore supplied to those files that lacked them during processing. Both original and supplied titles were taken from the press release lead in most cases. Researchers should keep this in mind as a file title may not represent all of the information disseminated within a press release.

Most files in the first three subseries contain multiple copies of the published press releases. Some also contain or are wholly comprised of supplementary documents to press releases such as reports and photographs.

physdesc.extent: About 1 Half LGL sized Hollinger box and 7.75 LTR sized Hollinger boxes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subseries contains News from the Ford Foundation press releases No. 1-295. The first three files contain collections of press releases from the early and mid-1950s rather than single releases like all of the other files. However, these files still belong to the numbered system of News from the Ford Foundation press releases as numbers 1, 2, and 3. Press releases within the first three files concern such topics as the Fund for the Republic, the Fund for Adult Education, the U.S. House of Representatives' investigations into tax-exempt foundations, agriculture and food production in India, the National Merit Scholarship Cooperation, Henry Ford II, the appointments of Ford Foundation Presidents H. Rowan Gaither Jr. and Henry T. Heald, and the Foreign Area Training Fellowships Program.
The subseries does not contain any significant gaps in its holdings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subseries contains News from the Ford Foundation press releases No. 370-771. Press releases in this subseries provide evidence of the Ford Foundation's expanded efforts to assist minority communities in the late 1960s.

The subseries originally contained a significant gap in its holdings. When Record Group 1, Accessions 2017:062 and 2017:078 were processed in February 2018, the subseries did not include News from the Ford Foundation press releases No. 676-735 (July 1969 – July 1970). These press releases were later discovered in Record Group 2, Accession 2018:088. The decision was made during the processing of Record Group 2 to move the documents into Record Group 1 in order so that the relationship between the press releases could be better represented.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Original folder was labeled No. 537a. However, during processing, it was determined that the folder was likely mislabeled and that the file actually contained News from the Ford Foundation press release No. 437a. The original location of the file, the date of the material contained within the file, and the entry for a News from the Ford Foundation press release No. 437a. on the Ford Foundation container inventory form were all indicators of a mistake in the folder labeling.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subseries contains the job files for a number of Ford Foundation press releases created between 1990 and 1993. Instead of just including copies of published press releases (and sometimes supplementary documents) like the files in the first three subseries of Series 1, the files in this subseries provide evidence of the processes that edited, publicized, and disseminated the finished news announcements. Materials such as press release drafts, correspondence, invoices, contracts with publicity services, media outlet mailing lists, printing instructions, and package tracking forms help document these activities.

Job files are identified by the job numbers listed in the file names. The Ford Foundation Office of Reports does not appear to have had the same level of responsibility in the creation of these files as it did with the 1951-1975 press release files in the first three subseries of Series 1. Both the Office of Reports and the Office of Communications appear to have helped create the files. Closer analysis of the subseries materials may better reveal the relationship between the two entities.

did.langmaterial: Within the series, materials are predominately in English, yet there are also many files containing one or more press clippings in Spanish. Press clippings in any language other than English or Spanish are noted at the file level.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The series was broken into four subseries during processing in order to represent identified systems of organization found within the record group as well as to facilitate improved user access to the large number of files encompassed by the series. The first three subseries comprise the record group's total amount of original press clippings selected by Burrelle's Information Services and Luce Press Clippings for the Ford Foundation. In contrast, the fourth subseries consists of bound collections of press clipping photocopies prepared by the Ford Foundation Office of Reports.

Box contents and sequential relationships between record group containers did not reveal a uniform system of arrangement imposed by the records' creators for the original Burrelle's and Luce press clippings. Original order has been maintained in this regard, so users will find that files within the first three subseries are not in chronological order and that files concerning the same subject or program area are not all grouped together. Nevertheless, the creation of subseries based primarily on the original box numbers and groupings did highlight discrete patterns of arrangement that the Ford Foundation Office of Communications and the other entities involved in the creation/custodianship of the records must have used. These patterns likely represent evolving trends in how the records' creators organized the press clippings over time as well as conscious decisions the creators made when deciding what files to group together in the boxes.
The series arrangement is as follows:
Series 2. Subseries 1. Clippings, announcements, and miscellaneous press media, 1964-1998
Series 2. Subseries 2. Clippings and announcements, 1992-1998
Series 2. Subseries 3. Clippings and announcements, 1992-2002
Series 2. Subseries 4. Comment on the Ford Foundation issues, 1974-1988

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series is comprised of three main types of documents: 1) original press clippings collected by Burelle's Information Services and Luce Press Clippings for the Ford Foundation; 2) announcements transmitted to the Ford Foundation by Burrelle's and Luce about press mentions of the Foundation; and 3) various issues of the Comment on the Ford Foundation publication. The first two types make up Subseries 1, 2, and 3 of Series 2 while the third type makes up Subseries 4.

Burrelle's and Luce were external press clipping services that monitored newspapers and other types of print media for references to the Ford Foundation. The announcements they transmitted to the Ford Foundation were called Burrelle's NewsExpress and Luce AM Newsbreak respectively. Materials at the end of Series 2 Subseries 3 discuss a software program called Burrelle's Information Office (BIO) that likely changed how the Ford Foundation received its press clipping services during the early 2000s.

Press clips are identified by the tags that the different clipping service providers stuck to them. They detail the name of the newspaper, the date of the article, and the name of the clipping service. Clips were organized into files in order to document news coverage on certain programs, individuals, and topics. Programs like Human Rights and International Cooperation (HRIC), Education, Media, Arts, and Culture (EMAC), Asset Building and Community Development (ASSETS), and Innovations in American Government Awards have the most amount of files devoted to their news coverage. Prominently featured individuals in the series include Ford Foundation Presidents McGeorge Bundy, Franklin Thomas, and Susan Berresford. There are also a number of files that contain miscellaneous mentions of the Ford Foundation.
In addition to clippings and announcements, the first three subseries contain press logs, correspondence, and internal memoranda as well as some press media material like speeches and press releases.

The Comment on the Ford Foundation publications are bound collections of press clipping photocopies that provided news coverage on the Ford Foundation's activities for a specific period of time or in relation to a specific subject.

did.unittitle: Clippings, announcements, and miscellaneous press media

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The 1996-1998 press clippings derive from the same period as the clippings in Series 2 Subseries 2 and in Series 2 Subseries 3. Several miscellaneous press clipping files are included as they are in the aforementioned subseries, and Series 2 Subseries 1 also includes several files housing press clippings related to the Innovations in American Government Awards Program like the other two subseries. However, the Innovations files in this subseries have a more specific focus than the other Innovations files. File names indicate topical themes such as arts and education. Another organizational difference between the 1996-1998 press clipping files in Series 2 Subseries 1 and their counterparts in the latter two subseries centers around the files' lack of program focus. The Innovations in American Government Awards Program is the only Ford Foundation program featured in the arrangement scheme of Subseries 1 whereas many of the press clippings in Subseries 2 and Subseries 3 are grouped together based on program area.

The 1977-1982 and 1965-1972 press clipping files in Subseries 1 originate from earlier time periods than the files in Subseries 2 and 3 that only house clippings from the 1990s and early 2000s. These files chiefly concern the topics of Ford Foundation Presidents Franklin Thomas and McGeorge Bundy, the new Ford Foundation headquarters building in New York City, and the United Nations Development Corporation. Files related to Franklin Thomas actually hold other types of material besides press clippings. They include speeches, magazines, and press releases as well.
The subseries also houses a file containing faxes from the Ford Foundation Office of Communications to the Chronicle of Philanthropy magazine company. These faxes originate from the early 1990s.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains press clippings from between 1992 and 1998 with the bulk of its holdings originating from 1994-1996. Its focus on the mid-1990s highlights organizational changes that transformed various Ford Foundation programs during the latter half of the decade. Unlike Series 2 Subseries 3, this subseries contains files documenting the Governance and Public Policy Program (GPP), the International Affairs Program (IA), the Rights and Social Justice Program (RSJ), and the Education and Culture Program. These programs would change and consolidate to become the Human Rights and International Cooperation Program (HRIC) and the Education, Media, Arts, and Culture Program (EMAC) that are more heavily featured in the next subseries.

Furthermore, several of the arrangement choices imposed on the subseries by the records' creators differentiate it from Series 2 Subseries 1 and Series 2 Subseries 3. It is the only subseries to group press clippings together based on newspaper source. For example, there are a few files that just contain press clippings from the Chicago Tribune, and there are a few files that just contain files from the New York Times. Subseries 2 is also the only subseries that includes files that specifically concern the activities of the Ford Foundation regional offices.

did.unittitle: Clippings related to Ford Foundation publications
Regional Offices: Africa and Middle East programs

physdesc.extent: About 17.25 LGL size Hollinger boxes and 2.5 LTR size Hollinger boxes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains press clippings from between 1992 and 2002 with the bulk of its holdings originating from the late 1990s and the early 2000s. Many of the files focus on the Ford Foundation's Human Rights and International Cooperation Program (HRIC), Education, Media, Arts, and Culture Program (EMAC), Asset Building and Community Development Program (ASSETS), and Innovations in American Government Awards Program. It appears that the records' creators attempted to use the files to document the various programs by month rather than document them by year as they had done in Series 2 Subseries 2. They used the same organizational scheme for the subseries' many files holding Luce AM Newsbreak and Burrelle's NewsExpress announcements.

A group of files near the end of the subseries contains documents that indicate a potential change in how the Ford Foundation collected press mentions of its activities during the early 2000s. Correspondence and various promotional materials discuss Burrelle's Information Office, a software program for managing and receiving media information.

processinfo.p: Documents within the file were found loose within their original storage container. They were grouped together into a file during accessioning and then described during processing. Several of the documents were likely displaced from the empty Luce AM Newsbreak Announcements 2001 May (Folder 1221) and 2001 June (Folder 1222) files before the collection's ingestion by the RAC.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subseries contains Issue 55 and Issues 62-87 of the Comment on the Ford Foundation publication. The Comment on the Ford Foundation publications are bound collections of press clipping photocopies that provided news coverage on the Ford Foundation's activities. Regular issues provided coverage on a specific period of time while Special Issues provided coverage on specific topics. Subsections in regular issues are based on Ford Foundation program areas while subsections in Special Issues are based on article type (such as editorial or magazine).
Some of the Comment on the Ford Foundation issues discuss changes that affected the clipping services that the Ford Foundation received during the late 1970s and early 1980s.

physdesc.extent: 2 LGL size Hollinger boxes and 1 Half-LGL size Hollinger box

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series consists of materials that the Ford Foundation created as part of its efforts to brief the public on recent and upcoming activities. Press conferences and press releases appear to be the two main vehicles that the Foundation used to share news information. In regards to press conferences, items like correspondence, memos, invitations, invitation lists, registration lists, flyers, and pamphlets provide evidence of the Ford Foundation trying to organize and publicize such news briefing events. Moreover, some files within the series contain transcripts of the press conferences. These items provide evidence of the actual events.

Although the press releases in the series originate from the same time period as the press releases in Series 1, they are not part of the numbered system of News from the Ford Foundation press releases found within that series. The records creators may have been deliberate when deciding to group them here with the press conference documentation rather than with the News from the Ford Foundation press releases. The series provides a more comprehensive view of the Ford Foundation's media dissemination strategy and activities between 1960 and 1977 because it includes both press conference and press release materials. (In Record Group 2, press release job files with this sort of job number were housed with job files labeled with the other form of job number. They were all thus similarly described as press job files in Record Group 2 Series 1 Subseries 3.)

It is unclear if the job numbers listed on some of the files within the series share any relationship to the press release job files in Series 1. They were not applied consistently like they were on the Series 1 job files, and they do not appear to be structured in the same way. The first two digits in the Series 1 job files most likely correspond to the year in which a file was created. No such meaning seems to apply to the first two digits of the job numbers found within Series 3.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series chiefly contains transcripts of public broadcasts from radio and television programs that mentioned the Ford Foundation during the early and mid-1950s. These transcripts were titled Texts of Broadcasts and were provided to the Ford Foundation by the manuscript service, Radio Reports Inc. In addition to including a transcript of a program that discussed the Ford Foundation, a Texts of Broadcasts report generally detailed information like the names of the program, the broadcaster, and the network as well as the date and time of the program.

The comments transcribed in the Texts of Broadcasts reports document how between 1953 and 1955 various radio and television programs mentioned the Ford Foundation in relation to such subjects as education, the Fund for the Republic, mental health research, and the U.S. House of Representatives' investigations into tax-exempt foundations.

The series also houses a file containing a small number of press releases from the 1950s. These releases do not appear to belong to the numbered system of News from the Ford Foundation press releases that is found in Series 1. They were found in the same box as the radio and television press media materials and are therefore represented in the same series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series is comprised of four magazine articles from the late 1960s. The first three articles originated from Fortune Magazine and are titled "Let's Not Fence in the Foundations", "McGeorge Bundy and the New Foundation Style", and "The Granite, Glass and Garden Community". These articles were extracted from the issues that published them whereas the fourth article - "A Grant to Beauty" published by Life Magazine – was kept in the complete magazine.
Several of the articles within the series focus upon the architecture and design of the new Ford Foundation headquarters building in New York City.
